questions.question: Define relative atomic mass.
questions.answer: The weighted mean mass of an atom of an element compared with one-twelfth of the mass of an atom of carbon-12.

questions.question: Describe how ions are produced in a time-of-flight mass spectrometer.
questions.answer: Sample is bombarded by high-energy electrons which knock out electrons to form positive ions.

questions.question: Explain why isotopes of the same element have the same chemical properties.
questions.answer: They have the same electron configuration.

questions.question: State the trend in first ionisation energy across Period 3.
questions.answer: General increase due to increasing nuclear charge with similar shielding.

questions.question: Explain why the first ionisation energy of aluminium is lower than that of magnesium.
questions.answer: Aluminium has its outer electron in the 3p subshell which is higher in energy than the 3s subshell in magnesium.

questions.question: Explain why sulfur has a lower first ionisation energy than phosphorus.
questions.answer: Paired electrons in a 3p orbital in sulfur repel each other, reducing the energy needed to remove one.

questions.question: Define empirical formula.
questions.answer: The simplest whole-number ratio of atoms of each element in a compound.

questions.question: A compound contains 40% sulfur, 60% oxygen by mass. Determine its empirical formula.
questions.answer: S: 40/32 = 1.25; O: 60/16 = 3.75; ratio = 1:3 → empirical formula = SO₃

questions.question: Describe the movement of ions in electrolysis of molten sodium chloride.
questions.answer: Na⁺ ions move to the cathode and gain electrons. Cl⁻ ions move to the anode and lose electrons.

questions.question: Explain why ionic compounds have high melting points.
questions.answer: They have strong electrostatic attractions between oppositely charged ions which require large amounts of energy to break.

questions.question: Describe the shape of a water molecule and explain why it has that shape.
questions.answer: Bent (104.5°). Two bonding pairs and two lone pairs; lone pairs repel more strongly than bonding pairs.

questions.question: State the meaning of the term electronegativity.
questions.answer: The ability of an atom to attract the bonding electrons in a covalent bond.

questions.question: Explain why hydrogen chloride is a polar molecule.
questions.answer: Chlorine is more electronegative than hydrogen, creating a dipole with δ− on Cl and δ+ on H.

questions.question: State and explain the trend in boiling points of noble gases from helium to xenon.
questions.answer: Boiling points increase due to increasing number of electrons, causing stronger London dispersion forces.

questions.question: Explain why graphite conducts electricity but diamond does not.
questions.answer: Graphite has delocalised electrons between layers; diamond has no delocalised electrons.

questions.question: Define the term metallic bonding.
questions.answer: Electrostatic attraction between positive metal ions and a sea of delocalised electrons.

questions.question: Explain why magnesium has a higher melting point than sodium.
questions.answer: Mg²⁺ ions have a greater charge and more delocalised electrons, resulting in stronger metallic bonding.

questions.question: State the ideal gas equation.
questions.answer: pV = nRT

questions.question: Calculate the number of moles in 4.8 g of magnesium. (Ar Mg = 24.0)
State one use of mass spectrometry.
questions.answer: To determine the relative isotopic abundances of elements.
